review_title: Micromanaging and Racist undertones from management
job_title: Academic Advisor in Upper Darby, PA
pros: Working with students to improve their wellbeing on campus.
cons: Low pay, admin staff didn’t focus much on students being successful and was more than happy to push jobs and task off to anyone else. Admin staff also was very cliquey with students and would help some while, leaving others to fend for themselves. People of color in the workspace was always heavily scrutinized and micromanaged to a degree that wasn’t seen in other co-workers/staff. Other coworkers were also happy to steal ideas from young staff members in order to boost the department and their own egos.

review_title: Want to love it but it's complicated
pros: The mission statement! The students are, for the most part, eager to learn and embrace the mission statement. The faculty works both ends of the candle to try to meet the huge needs.
cons: There has been a huge turnover since the new leadership (and to be fair-- the pandemic) has made things harder. The budget is always the elephant in the room to explain the lack of resources. Finger-pointing culture has gotten worse.

review_title: A small college that's barely surviving
pros: I was attracted to the job because it looked like a great opportunity.  Because the college was so behind the curve on so many levels (e.g. facilities, quality of faculty, quality of instruction) I got the impression that it was willing to take some chances to make up for lost time.  Some of the younger faculty members were good colleagues and nice people.
cons:
The entire institution is on life support.  There is a perennial financial crisis.  Salaries are the lowest I have ever seen.  Turnover in every area is extremely high.  The college is understaffed.  When I left in 2011, there were more academic programs (26)  than full-time faculty members (23.)  The entire college graduates less than 100 students each year and is completely tuition-dependent.  You can do the math; this place is not going to survive.    

Rosemont used to be a quaint, tiny women's college.  The demand for such an institution died twenty-five years ago; the college finally went co-ed five years ago; the organizational culture remains the same.  The mantra is that things are going to get better, yet there is no innovation and there are no resources.  How it will change, then, is anyone's guess.

review_title: This is a very exclusive environment because it's small and everyone knows each other.
pros: The classroom size is very small. The campus has ample parking and is easy to access.  There is office space for adjuncts and the copier is accessible (no need for passcodes).
cons: Since the campus is so small a newcomer is viewed as a novelty.  The students all know each other and act like middle schoolers who are trying to manipulate the environment.  They are not used to doing serious work, showing up to class consistently or arriving to class on time.

pros: As a smaller institution there are a lot of great opportunities in getting to know the student body and also the staff of the other departments.
cons: There is not much room for opportunity or growth. Many people hold multiple titles and salaries don't reflect said titles.

pros: Excellent Professional Development. Team environment. Stipend is decent and single room w/ bathroom. Always provides top of the line training.
cons: Management sometimes doesn't understand your other commitments because it is small campus.
